alert.note: Alert for Methow Valley; Okanogan Valley (Washington) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Spokane (Eastern Washington and Northern Idaho)
info.headline: Red Flag Warning issued July 15 at 2:55PM PDT until July 17 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS Spokane
info.description: ...DRY, BREEZY TO WINDY CONDITIONS LATE SUNDAY INTO MONDAY... .The breakdown of a hot ridge of high pressure and the arrival of a dry cold front will bring critical fire conditions to much of central and eastern Washington Sunday into Monday. Ahead of the front Sunday afternoon, hot south or southwest winds are expected to develop across central and north central Washington. Then on Monday, strong westerly winds will blow across central and eastern Washington in the wake the cold front. ...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FROM 5 PM SUNDAY TO 11 PM PDT MONDAY FOR WIND AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR THE METHOW AND OKANOGAN VALLEYS... The National Weather Service in Spokane has issued a Red Flag Warning for wind and low relative humidity, which is in effect from 5 PM Sunday to 11 PM PDT Monday. The Fire Weather Watch is no longer in effect. * Affected Area: Fire Weather Zone 703 Okanogan Valley (Zone 703) and Fire Weather Zone 704 Methow Valley (Zone 704), mainly the southern portions. * Winds: South-southwest 13 to 20 mph with local gusts to 30 mph Sunday evening then becoming west-northwest 15 to 25 mph with gusts up to 40 mph by Monday afternoon. * Relative Humidities: 11 to 18 percent Sunday and 19 to 28 percent Monday. * Impacts: The dry, gusty winds will be more pronounced south of Omak and south of Twisp in the late afternoon and evening hours. Temperatures near 100 Sunday afternoon combined with dry winds will lead to the potential for rapid spread of any new fires. Despite cooler temperatures and an increase in humidity Monday, strong wind are expected.
info.instruction: A Red Flag Warning means that critical fire weather conditions are either occurring now....or will shortly. A combination of strong winds...low relative humidity...and warm temperatures can contribute to extreme fire behavior.
